column13:
based in the Bournemouth area is seeking a Front End Developer to work on various projects developing mobile and digital applications within the MedTech sector.

This company currently work with various healthcare providers creating applications that are used by thousands of people daily. You'll be involved in creating both web and mobile applications utilising the latest JavaScript frameworks.

This is great role for an experienced Front End Developer to join the business and work on the latest releases for healthcare providers across the globe

You will join an Agile SCRUM team working closely with our clients and project managers.

The role will be to maintain and develop new functionality for our innovative online healthcare platform and pharmacy websites. The right candidate will be self-motivated and have a passion for technology.

- Big project experience with good software engineering skills

The company are a growing family business where you will be valued as an individual and encouraged to contribute to design decisions. The hours are flexible and our working environment is relaxed.

The successful Front End Developer will have proven experience working with both web and mobile applications and be particularly strong in React Front End.

To apply for the Front End Developer position please apply to this advert or contact me on LinkedIn

column11: 'title': 'Fields understands rivalries going into game against Packers | The China Post
column13: 'body': 'Fields understands rivalries going into game against Packers October 14
column14: 2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print\n\nLAKE FOREST
column15: Ill. (AP) -- Playing a bitter rival is nothing new for Chicago Bears quarterback Justin Fields.\n\nFacing the Green Bay Packers with first place on the line Sunday at Soldier Field in one of the NFL\'s oldest rivalries has some similarities to the annual Michigan and Ohio State matchup
column16: so Fields feels ready in this regard.\n\n"I mean
column19: Fields said. I\'ve been in the position before. I wouldn\'t say it totally prepares me for this
column20: but I have a pretty good idea of what a big rivalry game looks like."\n\nFields\' experience at Ohio State against Michigan comes from just one game his junior year
column21:
but it was a memorable one. He completed 14 of 25 for 302 yards and four touchdowns in a 56-27 Buckeyes' win. The pandemic wiped out his chance to face Michigan again as a senior.

His best memories of it extended beyond just winning.

"Trash talk before the game
column23: fans talking trash and stuff like that
column25: Fields said. Hearing what they say
column26: and the nonsense coming out of their mouths always gave me a good laugh before the game.\n\n"I mean
column28: just the competition that goes with it. Just the excitement
column29:
and just the competition and stuff like that."

The excitement will be different this time because he's squaring off against Aaron Rodgers for the first time. The Packers have a 21-5 record against the Bears with Rodgers starting.

"I'm excited
column30:
Fields said. Of course he's a Hall of Fame quarterback. He's a great quarterback. He's been playing since as long as I can remember.

"I know it's gonna be a good matchup between him and our defense. Our defense has been playing well. I'm excited to see him play."

Fields was 9 years old when Rodgers made his first NFL start in his third season in 2008 with Green Bay
column31: and he has developed an appreciation for the Packers quarterback\'s playing style.\n\n"I just like how he\'s always in rhythm when he plays the game
column32:
Fields said. That's a piece of his game that I try to emulate in mine."

Fields had an individual rivalry in college with Clemson's Trevor Lawrence but calls this different.

"Of course me and Trevor faced off a couple times in college
column34: I don\'t look at it as a matchup between me and Aaron like I didn\'t look at it as a matchup back then between me and Trevor.\n\n"I\'m simply doing whatever I need to do to help my team win. If that\'s hand the ball off 80 times during a game or throw for however so many yards
column35: that\'s what I\'m going to do. I\'m not worried about comparisons between touchdowns
column36:
stats. I'm worried about winning. That's it."

The Bears no doubt would like to see Fields' passing game emulate some of Rodgers' success.

Although they have gained some momentum with two straight wins
column37: their rookie quarterback has been helped along by a revived defense that is now ranked eighth in the NFL
column38: and a running game prospering even without injured running back David Montgomery.\n\nWhen Damien Williams and Khalil Herbert both had more than 15 carries against the Raiders in a 20-9 victory on Sunday
column39: it marked the first time since 2010 the Bears had two backs make 15 or more carries in a game. The result was 143 rushing yards.\n\n"You have more of those 4
column42: 7s (yards) than we\'ve had in the past where at times there\'s been 1s and 2s
column43: Bears coach Matt Nagy said. And so I think that helps out your second down
column44: which can help out your third down. And that\'s just a total compliment to the players and the coaches for really creating that identity."\n\nFields has struggled with consistency
column45: like most rookie passers. He has completed 51.4% (37 of 72) for 458 yards with one touchdown and two interceptions. He has a 64.5 passer rating.\n\n"I think we have a good feel of who he is and how he\'s growing each week
column46: Nagy said. I think we feel good about that and how we can continue to help grow him."\n\nNOTES: Fields suffered knee and rib injuries in the game Sunday and left briefly before returning. He went through a full practice on Wednesday and was removed from the injury report. ... The Bears were without outside linebacker Khalil Mack (foot)
column47:
wide receiver Allen Robinson (ankle) and defensive end Akiem Hicks (groin) at Wednesday's practice.

More AP NFL: https://apnews.com/tag/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL

column11: 'title': "Fast start by Packers' Adams has opponents feeling déjà vu | The China Post
column13: 'body': 'Fast start by Packers\' Adams has opponents feeling déjà vu October 14
column14: 2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print\n\nGREEN BAY
column15:
Wis. (AP) -- Green Bay Packers wide receiver Davante Adams says he occasionally is in the process of making a catch when he flashes back to a similar play he made months or years earlier.

Packers opponents must be feeling a similar sense of déjà vu this season as Adams continues producing at a level that could earn him All-Pro honors for a second straight season.

Last year
column16: Adams became the first player in NFL history to have at least 100 receptions and 18 touchdown catches in the same season. Although he has only reached the end zone twice this year
column17: Adams is on pace to exceed last year\'s totals in catches and yards receiving.\n\n"He\'s got people draped all over him and it doesn\'t matter
column18:
Packers coach Matt LaFleur said after Adams had a career-high 206 yards receiving Sunday in a 25-22 overtime victory at Cincinnati. He finds a way to do it every time."

Adams said after that game that he had told a few relatives beforehand he felt he might get a career high.

He also talked about how he sometimes catches a pass and subconsciously thinks back to plays he's made before. Adams referred to it as "some weird 'That's So Raven' (stuff)"
column19: a reference to the Disney Channel sitcom from the early 2000s featuring a teenage girl with psychic abilities.\n\nAdams went into more detail about that Wednesday. He said it happens maybe a few times a year
column20: usually on long-developing plays like deep patterns.\n\n"I\'ll be running
column21: the ball will be in the air and I\'ll feel like I\'ve been in that moment before
column22: Adams said. It\'s basically déjà vu
column24:
I guess you could say."

Sometimes the flashbacks aren't about catches he has made. They also can be about hits he's absorbed. He cited an example from his college career at Fresno State.

"Literally in the air
column26: (I was) thinking about how that same thing happened before against Nevada
column27: Adams said. Same type of situation. I like it more when it happens on positive plays
column28: but sometimes I\'ll have it when I\'m getting flipped in the air
column29:
too."

Adams said he doesn't recall this ever happening to him during his childhood. The flashbacks occurred as he got older.

"I think I had to kind of grow into that superpower
column30:
Adams quipped.

This season also has revealed one of Adams' other talents: his ability to stay focused.

Adams, who is in the final year of his contract, said at the start of training camp he wouldn't let any concerns about his future distract him this season. Adams noted how he managed to avoid worrying about the draft his final season at Fresno State and responded by catching 24 touchdown passes that year.

He has lived up to those words while helping the Packers (4-1) win four in a row.

Adams heads into Sunday's game at Chicago (3-1) with 42 catches for 579 yards to lead the NFL in both categories. Adams had a franchise-record 115 catches for 1,374 yards and 18 touchdowns last season.

He's just so talented
column31: quarterback Aaron Rodgers said after the Bengals game. Even when you know that I\'m probably going to him
column32:
he still finds a way to get open and makes a big catch and breaks a tackle. The guy is a special player."

Adams still sees room for improvement. He wants to boost those touchdown totals.

"Every time I get an opportunity down there
column33: whether I\'m doubled or singled up
column34: I\'m going to try to come down with it
column35:
Adams said. Make sure we make them count."

Follow Steve Megargee at https://twitter.com/stevemegargee

More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL

column12: new faces finding production at linebacker for Patriots | The China Post
column15: new faces finding production at linebacker for Patriots October 14
column16: 2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print\n\nFOXBOROUGH
column17: Mass. (AP) -- When the Patriots have played well on defense in recent years
column18: it usually has meant they\'ve gotten good play at linebacker.\n\nThat has been the case again this season with linebacker Matt Judon
column19: one of their key offseason additions
column20: thriving in his first year in New England\'s system.\n\nHe\'s leading the team with 6 1/2 sacks and has brought a gregarious personality to the locker room that has fit right in with a group that includes veterans such as Dont\'a Hightower
column21: Kyle Van Noy and Jamie Collins
column22: who was signed last week to begin his third stint with the team.\n\nIt has helped set the tone for a unit that enters the week ranked fifth in the NFL
column23: allowing 317 yards and 18.4 points per game. The Patriots will need all of them to be at their best this week as they prepare to host a Dallas Cowboys offense that is ranked second in the NFL
column24:
averaging 439.6 yards per game.

New England will also be looking for a bit of redemption after giving up three touchdown passes and more than 300 yards passing to Houston rookie Davis Mills last week.

"If we're gonna be a good football team
column25: we\'re gonna have to prove it
column26: Judon said. Nobody\'s gonna give it to us."\n\nThe challenge against the Cowboys begins with trying to contain a quarterback in Dak Prescott who is dangerous both inside and outside the pocket
column27: and is backed up by the dynamic running back duo of Ezekiel Elliott and Tony Pollard.\n\n"The skill players
column28: you can damn near put them up against anybody up in the league as far as talent or production overall
column29: however you want to look at it
column30: Hightower said. They\'re talented on each level or each tier of their offense."\n\nHightower
column31: Van Noy and Collins all shared the field together in 2019
column32: when the Patriots last beat the Cowboys 13-9 at Gillette Stadium. The trio led a group of linebackers which dubbed themselves "the boogeymen" as they combined for 19 sacks that season. They also ranked in the top four on the team in tackles.\n\nAfter barely having a chance to dive back into the Patriots\' playbook last week
column33:
Collins played just three snaps against the Texans but registered a sack.

He said there was an instant familiarity walking back into the Patriots locker room.

"It's like going back home for the first time
column34: Collins said. I couldn\'t stop smiling. ... Just coming back in here and just knowing I can go out with these guys again for the third time. Three times
column35: that\'s big."\n\nAfter opting out in 2020 because of COVID-19 concerns
column37: Hightower is having one of the slowest starts to a season in his career. He has 19 tackles
column38: but has yet to have a sack through the first five games. It\'s just the second time in his nine years in the NFL he has failed to have a sack by this point in the season.\n\nIf his production has slipped
column39: Hightower hasn\'t noticed. And neither have his teammates.\n\n"I\'ve never been a numbers guy
column40: Hightower said. I\'m gonna do whatever I need to do for the team. Whether it\'s knock the (crap) out of lineman
column41: if I\'m supposed to have eight or 10 tackles a game or have eight sacks -- that\'s what I plan on doing. I\'m just gonna do my job. I\'m a trash man. I just play football."\n\nThat dirty work has included everything from setting picks to free up other players to making well-timed stunt calls. The willingness to fill those roles have been beneficial
column42: Judon said.\n\n"He does a lot of dirty jobs for us
column43: Judon said of Hightower. But he makes it look good."\n\nWhile Judon believes this defense is taking steps toward figuring out how to be consistent
column44: he said their identity will change week to week as they try to adapt and keep opponents guessing.\n\nThat will mean taking advantage of all their opportunities this rest of the season
column45: beginning Sunday against Dallas.\n\n"We\'ve got to change our style every week
column48: it stays the same. We want to play the upper end of football here and that never changes."\n\nNOTES: Running back Damien Harris (ribs)
column49:
right guard Shaq Mason (abdomen) and cornerback Shaun Wade (concussion) all sat out Wednesday's practice.

More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL

column11: 'title': 'Pac-12 aiming to build on 2021 NCAA Tournament run | The China Post
column13: 'body': '泰文主播大推這料理！道地美食「吃了會想媽媽」｜Thai nationals unveil best \'boat noodles\' in Taiwan! Pac-12 aiming to build on 2021 NCAA Tournament run October 14
column14: 2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print\n\nThe Pac-12 had been an afterthought in the NCAA Tournament in recent years
column15: the number of teams getting in dwindling
column16: the deep runs into the bracket rare.\n\nThe conference took a big turn last season with three teams reaching the Elite Eight and UCLA playing in the Final Four
column17:
changing national perceptions while boosting confidence around the league.

Now it's time to take that next step of consistently doing well in March.

"I'm really excited for the league with what we accomplished at the NCAA Tournament
column18: Arizona State coach Bobby Hurley said Wednesday from Pac-12 media day in San Francisco. It\'s what we\'ve been talking about in head coaches\' meetings for years. To have that success translate in the NCAA Tournament. Our conference
column19: people are viewing us different because of that success. We have good momentum."\n\nThe Pac-12 was arguably the best conference in last year\'s tournament
column21: Southern California and Oregon State all reached the Elite Eight. The Bruins were seconds away from reaching the NCAA championship game
column22: losing to Gonzaga on Jalen Suggs\' banked-in running 3-pointer at the buzzer.\n\nLed by preseason favorite UCLA
column23: the conference is again loaded with talent headed into the 2021-22 season and the deep runs last spring have buoyed the confidence of teams across the league that they can do it
column24: too.\n\n"It gave us a huge confidence boost
column25: especially Oregon State and the ride they had
column26: knowing we played them two really tough games
column27: Washington State coach Kyle Smith said. And just knowing
column28: I thought the league was good and to get that national respect
column29:
we were working out in the spring with our chests kind of puffed out."

ALL PAC-12

The 2021-22 preseason all-Pac-12 first team is a big one.

Instead of the usual five players on the first team
column30: this year\'s team has 10 and five on the second team.\n\nUCLA leads the way with three players: Johnny Juzang
column31: Tyger Campbell and Jaime Jacquez Jr. The first team also includes Oregon State\'s Warith Alatishe
column36:
Oregon's Will Richardson and Washington State's Noah Williams.

BIGGER DUCKS

Oregon was forced to go with a small lineup for most of last season after 6-foot-11 forward N'Faly Dante went down with a knee injury.

The Ducks will have more options this season with Dante expected to return and four players on the roster 6-11 or taller.

"It gives up some flexibility where we go with some of our matchups that we didn't have a year ago
column37: Oregon coach Dana Altman said. As a coaching staff
column38:
you like being able to play different ways. You like being able to change it up if something's not working. Those guys give us the flexibility to do that."

OREGON STATE EXPECTATIONS

Oregon State was picked to finish last in the Pac-12 in the preseason poll last year and went into the conference tournament as the No. 6 seed.

The Beavers became one of the surprises of March Madness
column39:
winning the Pac-12 Tournament then reaching their first Elite Eight since 1966 as a No. 12 seed.

Now they enter the new season with added expectations.

"The run we had last season
column41: Oregon State guard Jarod Lucas said. We can be happy about last season
column43: but here we are a month away from a new season. We\'re going in with the same mindset
column44: to win every game and get better in practice day in
column45:
day out."

The Beavers were picked to finish eighth in this year's preseason poll.

BATTEY THE LEADER

Battey has been a natural leader at Colorado
column46: though he was able to share some of the load last season with a veteran-laden roster that included one of the best players in program history
column47: point guard McKinley Wright IV.\n\nNow that Wright and others are gone
column48: the senior big man becomes the unquestioned leader on a team filled with new players -- a role he\'s still feeling out.\n\n"Last year
column49: we had a bunch of seniors where I didn\'t have to hold their hand so much
column53: I\'m really trying to bow the line of when to lead and when to let them figure it out for themselves
column54: let them learn. I\'m trying to fight that urge
column55:
lead when I need to and let them grow."

More AP college basketball: https://apnews.com/hub/College-basketball and http://www.twitter.com/AP_Top25

column11: 'title': 'Agilent Receives FDA Companion Diagnostic Approval for Ki-67 IHC MIB-1 pharmDx in High-Risk Early Breast Cancer'
column13: Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Agilent Technologies Inc. (NYSE: A) today announced its Ki-67 IHC MIB-1 pharmDx (Dako Omnis) is now FDA approved as an aid in identifying patients with early breast cancer (EBC) at high risk of disease recurrence
column14: for whom adjuvant treatment with Verzenio® (abemaciclib) in combination with endocrine therapy is being considered. This is the first IHC assay measuring Ki-67 expression to receive FDA approval in the context of treatment with Verzenio and was developed in collaboration with Eli Lilly and Company.\n\nUnderstanding the risk of recurrence in EBC is vital for informing disease management
column15: as identifying patients at high risk can provide clarity for patients as well as facilitate treatment decisions to potentially improve outcomes. Conventional methods for evaluating the risk of recurrence in EBC are based on staging and are performed according to standard clinical and pathological features of the disease. However
column16: these standard features may not capture the full risk of recurrence for individuals with EBC.\n\nThe American Joint Committee on Cancer has identified the Ki-67 biomarker as Level of Evidence III in diagnosing EBC due to its association with cellular proliferation. Ki-67 is thus an important component of comprehensive risk assessment
column17: but it has been inconsistently applied in the past.1\n\n"Agilent\'s Ki-67 IHC MIB-1 pharmDx (Dako Omnis) companion diagnostic assay for the Dako Omnis advanced staining platform has been designed and tested to aid in evaluating risk of recurrence in early breast cancer (EBC)
column18: said Sam Raha, president of Agilent\'s Diagnostics and Genomics Group. Its approval establishes a clinically relevant standard for recurrence risk assessment in EBC so that more high-risk patients who may experience clinical benefit from treatment with Verzenio are identified."\n\nThis approval builds on Agilent\'s previous successes in expanding the clinical applicability of therapeutic biomarker analysis
column19:
further cementing the company's position as a provider of diagnostic assays that deliver high quality and ease of implementation.

About Agilent Technologies

Agilent is a leader in life sciences
column22: delivering innovative technology solutions that provide trusted answers to researchers\' most challenging scientific questions. The company generated revenue of $5.34 billion in fiscal year 2020 and employs 16
column23: 400 people worldwide. Information about Agilent is available at www.agilent.com. To receive the latest Agilent news
column24: please subscribe to the Agilent Newsroom. Follow Agilent on LinkedIn
column36: A. Eighth Edition of the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual: Breast Cancer. J. Am. Coll. Surg. 2018

column11: 'title': 'The Latest: Montana at new high for COVID hospitalizations | The China Post
column13: 'body': 'The Latest: Montana at new high for COVID hospitalizations October 14
column14: 2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print\n\nHELENA
column15: Montana -- Montana has set a new high for the number of people hospitalized with COVID-19 -- 510.\n\nThe number reported Wednesday surpassed the previous high of 506 hospitalizations recorded Nov. 20
column17: before any coronavirus vaccines were available.\n\nGov. Greg Gianforte issued a statement urging Montanans to get vaccinated
column18: but added that "we will not mandate them."\n\nMeanwhile
column21: shifted its middle and high school classes to remote learning to slow the spread of the coronavirus among students. Officials said few students have used masks.\n\nThe school board voted Tuesday to have remote learning for its 740 middle and high school students until Oct. 25
column22:
because there are 17 coronavirus cases each at Park High School and Sleeping Giant Middle School.

MORE ON THE PANDEMIC:

-- U.S. border residents rejoice in lifting of travel ban

-- FDA grapples with timing of booster for J&J COVID-19 vaccine

-- Russia
column23:
WHO differ on when approval will come for Sputnik V

-- Families of COVID-19 patients ask hospitals to rethink visitor policies

See all of AP's pandemic coverage at https://apnews.com/hub/coronavirus-pandemic

HERE'S WHAT ELSE IS HAPPENING:

HONOLULU -- Organizers are planning for the Honolulu Marathon even though it's not clear government officials will allow it to be held in December.

Hawaii Public Radio reports marathon organizers are frustrated that Honolulu is easing pandemic-related restrictions on large events but neither Hawaii's governor nor Honolulu's mayor have provided clarity about whether the marathon can happen with the thousands of participants it normally draws.

In 2019
column27:
000 from Japan.

Other large marathons in Boston and Chicago were held recently.

SAN DIEGO -- Beleaguered business owners and families separated by a nonessential travel ban are celebrating after the Biden administration says it will reopen U.S. land borders next month.

Travel across land borders from Canada and Mexico has been largely restricted to workers whose jobs are deemed essential. New rules will allow fully vaccinated foreign nationals to enter the U.S. regardless of the reason starting in early November.

Unlike air travel
column28: for which proof of a negative COVID-19 test is required before boarding a flight to enter the U.S.
column29: no testing will be required to enter the U.S. by land or sea
column30: provided the travelers meet the vaccination requirement.\n\nThe 19-month coronavirus restrictions had economic
column32: preventing shopping and cross-border family gatherings when relatives live on different sides of the border.\n\nIn Del Rio
column34: Mexican visitors account for about 65% of retail sales
column36: executive director of the chamber of commerce and visitors bureau in the city of 35
column38: we\'re like more of one community than two different communities
column39:
she said.

Fully vaccinated U.S. citizens and permanent residents have been allowed into Canada since August, provided they have waited at least two weeks since getting their second vaccine dose and can show proof of a recent negative COVID-19 test. Mexico has not enforced coronavirus entry procedures for land travelers.

PORTLAND, Maine -- A federal judge declined Wednesday to intervene to stop Democratic Gov. Janet Mills' requirement that health care workers be vaccinated against COVID-19 by the end of the month.

U.S. District Court Judge Jon Levy says none of the nine plaintiffs met the legal threshold for an injunction to halt the requirement to be fully vaccinated by Oct. 29 or lose their jobs.

Levy ruled the record indicates regular testing alone is not sufficient to stop the spread of the delta variant.

The speed of the delta variant's transmission outpaces test-result availability
column40:
he wrote. Daily testing, he wrote, would require use of rapid tests that are both less accurate and in short supply.

The judge concluded the plaintiffs were unable to show an injunction was in the public interest or that they had a strong likelihood of prevailing if the lawsuit moves forward. The Liberty Counsel, which filed the lawsuit in August, vowed to appeal.

BUCHAREST, Romania -- Doctors in Bucharest issued an open letter titled a cry of despair" as the country's overwhelmed health care system copes with record cases
column41:
hospitalizations and deaths.

The College of Physicians of Bucharest wrote a letter addressed to Romanians that says the medical system has "reached the limit."

On Wednesday
column44: bringing the total number of deaths to 40
column45:
461. Data from health authorities indicate that more than 90% of coronavirus patients who died last week were unvaccinated.

Hungary has agreed to provide care to several dozen COVID-19 patients from Romania in the coming days to help ease the burden on hospitals.

Dragos Zaharia
column46: a primary care doctor at Bucharest\'s Marius Nasta Institute of Pneumology
column47: thinks Romanian authorities should have enlisted a "famous personality" to lead the country\'s vaccination campaign.\n\n"Only anonymous guys are leading this fight
column48: Zaharia told The Associated Press. It\'s heartbreaking for us when we know that a lot of those who died could have lived
column49:
if they would have been vaccinated."

BOSTON -- More than 800 people who work for Boston have been suspended without pay for failing to comply with the city's coronavirus vaccine mandate.

Acting Mayor Kim Janey announced in August the city's roughly 18
column50: 000 employees would be required to either show proof of vaccination or submit to regular testing.\n\nJaney says the suspended employees who didn\'t meet Tuesday\'s initial deadline came from five "public facing" agencies
column53: the center for youth and families
column54: the disability commission and the age commission. Workers who continue to ignore the mandate face termination
column55: she said. The school department alone has about 11
column56: 000 employees.\n\nThe city is making plans to deal with potential staffing shortfalls
column57: which so far accounts for less than 1% of workers. Suspended employees can return to work by providing proof of a negative test.\n\nGENEVA -- The World Health Organization says the number of global coronavirus cases fell in the last week
column58: continuing a downward trend that began in late August.\n\nIn its latest weekly assessment of the pandemic published on Wednesday
column59: the U.N. health agency says there were about 2.8 million new cases and 46
column60: 000 confirmed deaths in the last week
column61: a drop of 7% and 10% respectively. Europe reported a 7% rise in cases
column62: while all other world regions reported a decrease.\n\nWHO says Europe also had the biggest rise in deaths in the previous week
column63: with 11% more COVID-19 deaths. WHO says the highest numbers of new cases in Europe were reported in Britain
column64: Turkey and Russia.\n\nThe biggest drops in cases came in Africa and the Western Pacific
column65: where case numbers fell by 32% and 27%
column66:
respectively. Deaths in both regions fell by more than a third.

WASHINGTON -- The Food and Drug Administration is wrestling with how to decide on booster doses of the single-shot Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine.

Other manufacturers want to offer boosters six months after primary vaccination. But J&J proposed a range of times
column67: from two months to six months. In a review posted Wednesday
column68: FDA scientists didn\'t reach a firm conclusion
column69: citing shortcomings with J&J\'s data.\n\nOn Thursday and Friday
column70:
an FDA advisory panel will recommend whether to back boosters of both the J&J and Moderna vaccines. An extra dose of Pfizer's vaccine already is available to certain Americans.

Pfizer and Moderna have provided the majority of U.S. COVID-19 vaccines. More than 170 million Americans have been fully vaccinated with those two-dose shots while less than 15 million Americans got the J&J shot.

MOSCOW -- The head of the Russian sovereign fund bankrolling the shot says Russia is ready to provide up to 300 million doses of its Sputnik V vaccine to the U.N.-backed COVAX initiative.

That's despite the lack of WHO approval and Sputnik V vaccine production issues that are drawing concerns worldwide. Russian Direct Investment Fund CEO Kirill Dmitriev and the World Health Organization had vastly different takes Wednesday on when the Russian vaccine would get WHO's stamp of approval.

Sputnik V is already being used in 70 countries around the world despite not yet authorized by the U.N. health agency. Some officials in countries
column72: have expressed concerns they aren\'t getting the vaccine\'s second shot in time to properly innoculate their people.\n\nMIAMI -- Families of COVID-19 patients are asking hospitals to rethink visitor policies a year and a half into the pandemic
column74:
000 people in the U.S.

The relatives say they're being denied the right to be with loved ones at a crucial time. Doctors also are increasingly telling hospitals to relax restrictions to allow patients to see their families.

Hospitals in at least a half-dozen states have loosened restrictions governing visits to COVID patients. Others
column77:
backed by studies and industry groups that indicate such policies have been crucial to keeping hospital-acquired infections low.

The University of Utah Health this year announced its hospitals would allow up to two adult visitors for the entire hospital stay with protective equipment and recently vaccinated or recovered from the virus. Many hospitals have made exceptions only for coronavirus patients who are about to die.

MOSCOW -- Russia has reported a record 984 daily coronavirus deaths amid a slow vaccination rate.

It's marked several record daily death tolls in the past few weeks. Infections have soared to near all-time highs
column79:
717 confirmed cases reported Wednesday.

The Kremlin has attributed the mounting contagion and deaths to slow vaccinations. Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin said Tuesday about 29% of the country's nearly 146 million people were fully vaccinated.

President Vladimir Putin emphasized the need to speed up the vaccination rate on Tuesday
column80:
but he also has cautioned against forcing people to get the shots. Health experts have attributed the slow pace of vaccination to widespread vaccine skepticism and disinformation.

The Kremlin has ruled out a new nationwide lockdown similar to the one during the first months of the pandemic that badly crippled the economy and dented Putin's ratings. It has delegated the power to enforce coronavirus restrictions to regional authorities.

The increased infections have increased the pressure on Russia's health care system. Speaking at a Cabinet meeting Tuesday
column81: Health Minister Mikhail Murashko said 11% of Russia\'s 235
column82: 000 hospitalized COVID-19 patients are in serious or critical condition.\n\nRussia\'s coronavirus task force has confirmed more than 7.8 million cases and 219
column83: 329 deaths -- the highest death toll in Europe. Russia trails the U.S (718
column88: 000) in confirmed global deaths.\n\nGENEVA -- The World Health Organization released a proposed list of 25 experts to advise it on the next steps in searching for the origins of the coronavirus after its earlier efforts were slammed for accommodating China
column89: where the first human cases were detected in late 2019.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday
column90: the U.N. health agency says its proposed experts -- including some who were on the original team that went to Wuhan to probe the origins of COVID-19 -- would be subject to a two-week public consultation period. Among the suggested members of the new team are Marion Koopmans of the Netherlands and Thea Fischer of Denmark
column91: who were on the WHO team that visited China in February. In a recent commentary
column93: Fischer and others said the search for the origins of COVID-19 had "stalled" and Chinese officials were still refusing to hand over some raw data.\n\nAfter the WHO-led team completed its China visit
column94: the experts released a report concluding the possibility the coronavirus leaked from a Wuhan lab was "extremely unlikely
column95: prompting criticism from outside scientists that the theory had not been properly vetted. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus later acknowledged it had been premature" to dismiss the lab theory.\n\nNumerous health experts and scientists have called for an independent investigation to be conducted beyond WHO
column96: pointing out the agency has no authority to compel countries
column98: to cooperate. China has said it welcomes further investigations of the coronavirus\' origins
column99: but in other countries. A recent review of U.S. intelligence ordered by President Joe Biden found inconclusive evidence whether the coronavirus originated in a laboratory.\n\nTAGScoronaviruscoronavirus pandemicCovid-19pandemic Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print Previous articleFrom cars to gasoline

column11: 'title': 'Lawyer who aided Trump subpoenaed by Jan. 6 committee | The China Post
column13: 'body': 'Lawyer who aided Trump subpoenaed by Jan. 6 committee October 14
column14:
2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print

WASHINGTON (AP) -- The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol has issued a subpoena to a former Justice Department lawyer who positioned himself as an ally of Donald Trump and aided the Republican president's efforts to challenge the results of the 2020 election.

The subpoena to Jeffrey Clark
column16:
came amid signs of a rapidly escalating congressional inquiry. At least three of the people who were involved in organizing and running the rally that preceded the violent riot have handed over documents in response to subpoenas from the committee.

The demands for documents and testimony from Clark reflect the committee's efforts to probe not only the deadly insurrection but also the tumult that roiled the Justice Department in the weeks leading up to it as Trump and his allies leaned on government lawyers to advance his baseless claims that the election results were fraudulent. Trump loyalists stormed the Capitol in an effort to disrupt the congressional certification of Democrat Joe Biden's victory

Clark
column17: an assistant attorney general in the Trump administration
column18: has emerged as a pivotal character in that saga. A Senate committee report issued last week shows how he championed Trump\'s efforts to undo the election results inside the Justice Department and clashed as a result with superiors who resisted the pressure
column19: culminating in a dramatic White House meeting at which Trump floated the idea of elevating Clark to attorney general.\n\n"The Select Committee\'s investigation has revealed credible evidence that you attempted to involve the Department of Justice in efforts to interrupt the peaceful transfer of power
column20: the chairman of the committee, Democratic Rep. Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, wrote in a letter to Clark announcing the subpoena.\n\nWhile Trump ultimately did not appoint Clark acting attorney general, Clark\'s efforts risked involving the Department of Justice in actions that lacked evidentiary foundation and threatened to subvert the rule of law
column21:
Thompson added.

The committee has scheduled a deposition for Oct. 29 and demanded documents by the same date. A lawyer for Clark declined to comment.

The Jan. 6 panel has so far sought testimony from a broad cast of witnesses, but its demands of Trump aides and associates are potentially complicated by Trump's vow to fight their cooperation on grounds of executive privilege.

Already one witness, Steve Bannon, has told the committee that he will not cooperate based on Trump's directive, though the committee has said it was engaging" with two other Trump officials -- former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows and former Defense Department official Kashyap Patel. It is also unclear whether Dan Scavino
column22: Trump\'s longtime social media director and one of his most loyal aides
column23: will cooperate.\n\nBiden formally rejected Trump\'s claim of executive privilege surrounding a tranche of documents requested from the former president\'s time in the White House
column24: and set up their potential release to Congress in mid-November. White House counsel Dana Remus wrote to the National Archives in a letter released Wednesday that Biden believes that "an assertion of executive privilege is not in the best interests of the United States."\n\nOthers
column27: including some of the 11 who organized or staffed the Trump rally that preceded the riot. They were given a Wednesday deadline to turn over documents and records
column28: and have also been asked to appear at separate depositions the committee has scheduled beginning this month.\n\nAmong those responding to the Wednesday deadline was Lyndon Brentnall
column29: whose firm was hired to provide event security that day. "All the documents and communications requested by the subpoena were handed in
column30: he told The Associated Press.\n\nBrentnall had previously said his firm had every intention" of complying with the select committee. "As far as we\'re concerned
column31: we ran security at a legally permitted event run in conjunction with the U.S. Secret Service and the Park Police
column32: he said.\n\nTwo longtime Trump campaign and White House staffers, Megan Powers and Hannah Salem, who were listed on the Jan 6. rally permit as operations manager for scheduling and guidance" and "operations manager for logistics and communications
column33:
have also provided documents or are planning to do so.

Powers, who served as the Trump reelection campaign's director of operations, intends to provide the requested documentation and to meet with the committee -- though it remains unclear what form such meetings will take, according to a person familiar with her response who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Many of the rioters who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6 marched up the National Mall after attending at least part of Trump's rally, where he had repeated his meritless claims of election fraud and implored the crowd to fight like hell."

The results of the election were confirmed by state officials and upheld by the courts. Trump's own attorney general
column35:
had said the Justice Department found no evidence of widespread fraud that could have overturned the results.

It remains unclear whether the others who were subpoenaed intend to cooperate. A committee spokesperson declined to comment Wednesday on the responses it had received and how many of the 11 were complying.

Members of the committee
column38: have threatened to pursue criminal contempt charges against subpoenaed witnesses who refuse to comply. A House vote would send those charges to the Department of Justice
column39:
which would then decide whether to prosecute.

The subpoena to Clark follows the release of a Senate Judiciary Committee report that documented extraordinary tensions within the senior ranks of the Justice Department in December and January as Trump and his allies prodded the law enforcement agency to help him in undoing the election.

The report from the committee's Democratic majority depicts Clark as a relentless advocate inside the building for Trump's efforts
column40: even presenting colleagues with a draft letter pushing Georgia officials to convene a special legislative session on the election results. Clark wanted the letter sent
column41: but superiors at the Justice Department refused.\n\n"We need to understand Mr. Clark\'s role in these efforts at the Justice Department and learn who was involved across the administration
column42: Thompson wrote.\n\nTwo additional organizers, Ali Alexander and Nathan Martin, as well as their Stop the Steal" organization
column44:
which are due Oct. 21.

Alexander wrote in a Telegram post Monday that the committee was "subpoenaing people in bad faith."

"So maybe this Select Committee is bogus?" he added. "Everyone is waiting to see what I'll do."

__

Colvin reported from New York and Smith from Providence
column45: Rhode Island. Associated Press writers Farnoush Amiri and Zeke Miller in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nShare LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print Previous articleThe Latest: Montana at new high for COVID hospitalizationsNext articleMental capacity at issue as Alabama man faces execution date 龔向華'

column12: heads toward Texas | The China Post
column16: 2021 Share LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print\n\nMEXICO CITY (AP) -- Tropical Storm Pamela weakened to a tropical depression Wednesday after slamming into Mexico\'s coast as a hurricane
column17: though forecasters warned that its rainy remnants could cause flooding in parts of Texas and Oklahoma in the coming days.\n\nPamela made landfall early Wednesday on Mexico\'s Pacific Coast about 40 miles (65 kilometers) north of the resort and port city of Mazatlan
column18:
where civil defense officials said wind and rain caused minor flooding but did little damage.

The U.S. National Hurricane Center said Pamela's winds had fallen to about 35 mph (55 kph) by late afternoon. It was centered 255 miles (415 kilometers) northeast of Mazatlan and moving northeast at 28 mph (44 kph).

Forecasters said the depression was likely to dissipate by evening
column19: but could still bring "considerable flash and urban flooding ... across portions of central Texas and southeastern Oklahoma."\n\nShare LINE Facebook Twitter Telegram WhatsApp Linkedin ReddIt Digg Email Print Previous articleMental capacity at issue as Alabama man faces execution dateNext articleRevolving door at CB spins again as Seahawks waive Flowers 龔向華'
